entry.title: WWDC18 Scholarships Information
entry.content: Wait, before we start, what is WWDC? Iâ€™ll add my description soon, but for now, check out the official website. Thank you all for being interested in Appleâ€™s Worldwide Developer Conference and this scholarship opportunity. I hope all of us could go together, to learn, and have fun! I know this article is a little bit long, but please read through this carefully before you start. If you have any questions, just ask me through messenger, or in the comment area below. Iâ€™ll be constantly updating this, and the Chinese version is available here. Important Dates Date Event April 1, 20:00 EDT Submission Due April 20 Announce Status June 3-8 Orientation + WWDC! General Information Please read the description carefully, as well as the terms and conditions. In summary, you are required to write a Playground â€“ an interactive program â€“ that is creative and technically accomplished. Things to Get You do NOT need a paid Apple Developer Account. Do you know whatâ€™s better than that? Youâ€™ll get one year of Apple Developer membership if you win! If you have a Mac, download Xcode from Mac App Store, or if you have an iPad, download Swift Playgrounds from App Store, or if you have a Windows, get a virtual machine or whatever that works. Learn Swift If you have an iPad, I highly recommend you to go through one of those â€œLearn to Codeâ€ playgrounds to get a general idea about what a legit playground should be like, in addition to the Swift programming language itself. At the same time, everyone by now should have either an iOS device or a Mac, please open (i)Books and get The Swift Programming Language. You can always choose to read it online as well. Most of you are already familiar with Java, so reading just â€œA Swift Tourâ€ should be adequate for you to understand this simple programming language. For those of you never learned programming before, just scan through that, and chapter 2 (Language Guide) will answer your questions. You do NOT need to read chapter 3 (Language Reference) and 4 (Revision History). General Stuff to Learn I Want to Write a 2D game You should learn SpriteKit. I Want to Write a 3D game You should learn SceneKit, but I hope youâ€™ve already had some sense of how 3D works and where to get your 3D models. A bonus for you, Apple talked about using SceneKit in the iPad version of Swift Playgrounds. Otherwise Well, UIKit itself can do a lot of stuff. To get started, follow Start Developing iOS Apps (Swift). If you have time, you may also want to have a general understanding of how view controllers work, maybe more about table views, or even iOS Apps in general. More About Playground No matter what, you should read the Markup Formatting Reference. Your Playground will look a lot better with this in conjunction with CustomPlaygroundQuickLookable/CustomPlaygroundDisplayConvertible. Mac, Xcode, and Playground It was first introduced back in 2014, and later in 2015 you can use the format mentioned above to author rich Playgrounds to better instruct your users. Here is a simple Swift Playground Book for you to get started, and you can also find other interesting ones from the Swift Blog, although many of them would be outdated and require some changes for them to work. iPad and Swift Playgrounds This app is first introduced in 2016 and updated again last year. iPad Playground has many features that a normal Xcode Playground doesnâ€™t have â€“ Cut Scenes written in html (a great place to inform your user whatâ€™s this chapter about), cover images, vocab lists, etc. To fully utilize those features, please read the Playground Book Format Reference, and experiment with this sample that allows you to send messages to a Swift Playground live view and saving data to its key-value store. Analysis Remember that your playground will be judged offline, the program can NOT require an account for sign in, and theyâ€™ll only spend 3 minutes in judging it, so think about what you are going to do. Even without thinking I can tell you many people will be doing augmented reality and machine learning; you can not imagine how easy it is to implement those fancy but scary stuff with ARKit and Core ML. Well, try to be creative, add some graphics and audios, and incorporate some of Appleâ€™s new technologies (even if they didnâ€™t mention about that)â€¦ For the first time, you are allowed to use open source frameworks (providing that you included their licenses correctly and explained why). Nonetheless, what you are going to submit is not just a normal program. I think these are some reasons why Apple prefers Playground over normal apps, and maybe you want to address some of them: user will be directed about what to do and informed of what is expected it provide an interactive way for the users to learn things through programming it sparks usersâ€™ interest in coding and encourages further participation â€¦(many more to add) Also, the â€œBeyond WWDCâ€ essay is very important. You should explain, in 500 words, how you share your coding knowledge and enthusiasm for computer science with others. Spend some time on this and revise it several times. However, that doesnâ€™t mean the playground itself isnâ€™t important. There were many amazing playgrounds, such as this one here, but the quality of the other ones varies. So my suggestion is analysis why some of them got accepted and some got rejected, see if you can resonate with former winners, and just try your best. If youâ€™d ever ask me if itâ€™s hard, Iâ€™ll answer yes but DOABLE. Just make sure you donâ€™t copy any othersâ€™ code â€“ the 2048 playground from last yearâ€™s submissions was rejected for this reason. Everything is doable if you try. Mr. Lau Good luck. â€“ Apollo (a.k.a Zhiyu Zhu, last yearâ€™s scholarship winner for submitting Karel the Robot Playground)

entry.title: æ„Ÿæƒ³ä¹‹åå†è¡¥
entry.content: Any real change implies the breakup of the world as one has always known it, the loss of all that gave one an identity, the end of safety. And at such a moment, unable to see and not daring to imagine what the future will now bring forth, one clings to what one knew, or thought one knew; to what one possessed or dreamed that one possessed. Yet, it is only when a man is able, without bitterness or self-pity, to surrender a dream he has long cherished or a privilege he has long possessed that he is set freeâ€”he has set himself freeâ€”for higher dreams, for greater privileges. James Baldwinâ€œFaulkner and Desegregationâ€Nobody Knows My Name

entry.title: LeetCode - 2. Add Two Numbers
entry.content: æœ¬æ¥è¯´ LeetCode å‡†å¤‡å…¨ç”¨ Swiftï¼Œï¼ˆè¿™é“é¢˜æ­£å¸¸åšæ³• Swift ä¹Ÿè¡Œï¼Œè¯¦è§æ­£ç¡®ç­”æ¡ˆï¼‰ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯æƒ³å·æ‡’ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªæ—¶å€™åªæœ‰é python è¿™ç§é€‚åˆå¤§æ•°æ®çš„æ‰è¡Œï¼Œæ¯•ç«Ÿè¿™é“é¢˜çš„æœ¬è´¨æ˜¯æŠŠä¸¤ä¸ªæ•°ç›¸åŠ ã€‚ You are given two non-empty linked lists representing two non-negative integers. The digits are stored in reverse order and each of their nodes contain a single digit. Add the two numbers and return it as a linked list. You may assume the two numbers do not contain any leading zero, except the number 0 itself. Input: (2 -> 4 -> 3) + (5 -> 6 -> 4) Output: 7 -> 0 -> 8 å®é™…ä¸Šè¿™å°±æ˜¯è®¡ç®— 342+465=807342 + 465 = 807342+465=807ï¼Œæ¯ä¸ªæ•°å­—åˆ†åˆ«æ˜¯å€’ç€å†™çš„ã€‚æ‰€ä»¥å…ˆ toInt é€’å½’æŠŠé“¾è¡¨è½¬æ¢æˆæ•´æ•°ï¼Œç„¶å toListNode æŠŠæ•´æ•°è½¬å›é“¾è¡¨ã€‚ä½†è¿™ç§ä¸è´Ÿè´£ä»»çš„å†™æ³• Swift ä¼šæº¢å‡ºï¼Œäºæ˜¯æ¢äº† pythonã€‚ 1234567891011toInt = lambda l: l and toInt(l.next) * 10 + l.val or 0def toListNode(i): base = None for c in str(i): new = ListNode(int(c)) new.next = base base = new return baseclass Solution: def addTwoNumbers(self, l1, l2): return toListNode(toInt(l1)+toInt(l2)) toListNode é‡Œè½¬å­—ç¬¦ä¸²å®Œå…¨æ˜¯ä¸å¾—å·²è€Œä¸ºã€‚æˆ‘ä¸€å¼€å§‹ï¼ˆä¹Ÿæ˜¯ StefanPochmannï¼‰ç”¨çš„æ–¹æ³•æ˜¯è¿™æ ·çš„ï¼š 12345def toListNode(i): this = ListNode(i % 10) if n > 9: this.next = toListNode(i / 10) return this æœ‰äº›è¹Šè··çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œåœ¨æ•°å­—å¤Ÿå¤§çš„æ—¶å€™ï¼Œä¼šå’Œæ­£ç¡®ç»“æœæœ‰äº›å‡ºå…¥ã€‚åŸå› ä¸æ˜ï¼Œéš¾ä¸æˆæ˜¯é™¤æ³•å¸¦æ¥çš„æµ®ç‚¹è¯¯å·®ï¼Ÿ

entry.title: Advanced CS Student Survey
entry.content: Dear Advanced APCS students, In order to provide an excellent learning environment for you in this coming school year, I would like you to help me answer the following questions, be as specific and detailed as possible, so that I can do a better job in terms of fulfilling your needs. Thank you for your time. Mr. Lau Why did you sign up to take this course? Be specific. Just interested; to learn. What do you expect to learn from this course? If you know nothing about the curriculum, just brainstorm by yourself and tell me something that you want to learn. Fully understand Big-O notation. Basic algorithms and data structures, and when/why to choose one over another. What did you do over the summer that is related to computing (summer camp, internship, self-learning, taking an online course, teaching other people)? Please tell me what you learned through this experience. Be as specific as possible. Mainly translating Stanfordâ€™s Developing iOS 10 Apps with Swift; read The Swift Programming Language (Beta). Wrote an app to post the translated subtitle to online video platform, practiced using recursion, HTTP request, async background queue, and Continuous Integration. Wrote a raffle app in Kotlin (Googleâ€™s new programming language for Android, basically Java), refreshed memory of Swing, learned a little about JavaFX. Read part of the K&R (The C Programming Language). Watched a short series of basic tutorials about HTML & CSS. Watched How GitHub uses GitHub series. Learned several git commands. Please check those topics that you know something about. Tell me something about each if possible. [x] Linked List: Holding a pointer to the previous/next Element. Easier to add/remove, harder to find index. [x] Recursion: Using itself in the definition of itself. Throws StackOverFlowException. [ ] Big-O notation [x] Stack: First (push) In, Last (pop) Out. How I deal with recursive methods. [x] Queue: FIFO. [x] Priority Queue: Queue, elements ordered by priority. [x] Hash Table: AKA Dictionary<K: AnyHashable, V: AnyObject>, mapping Key to Value. [ ] Heap [x] Tree: Nodes. May traverse in Pre/In/Post order (if should visit root first). [x] Binary Search Tree: Each node has max 2 child, with left < this < right, and each child is BST [x] Graph: (Un)directed edges connecting vertices. [ ] Depth first search [ ] Breadth first search [ ] Quicksort (and basically all other sorting algorithms) Your concerns about this course. Be specific and honest. Write as much as necessary! Big-O notation sounds/is quite confusing, it took me a long time to understand why merge sort is O(nlogn).

entry.title: GitHub's Swift Style Guide
entry.content: ä¸­æ–‡ç‰ˆæœ¬ When I was cleaning up my GitHub repos and stars, I found GitHubâ€™s style guide for Swift, and I find this 2nd most starred style guide quite amusing. Despite the fact that Xcode defaults to using 4 spaces for indentation (and we can clearly see the impact by checking tabs-or-spaces), the style guide suggests using tabs instead. Iâ€™m totally fine with that, but I can easily tell there are some disagreements among the contributors: 1234567var myGreatProperty: Int { return 4}subscript(index: Int) -> T { return objects[index]} But thereâ€™s more. For now (2017 Auguest 23), there are three Swift repos under GitHubâ€™s main account â€“ one source, two forks. Well, then letâ€™s focus on SoftU2F, the ONLY Swift repository GitHub actually owns. Isnâ€™t it natural for me to expect this repo to follow GitHubâ€™s own style guide? But ironically, even SoftU2F is NOT doing that! In conclusion, seems that GitHub is not interested in styling their Swift code, and thus the GitHub community (or at least the 4k stargazers) has no actual intention to follow GitHubâ€™s style guide, too.

entry.title: A "Good" Letter to Next Years' APCSA Students
entry.content: This letter was included into the summer packet with minor modifications 12for (Student student : APCSA.future.students) System.out.print("Hello "+ student.name); Youâ€™ll learn about computer science and Java here. You wonâ€™t be learning about how to write visually attractive programs for the most of the times, but what you learn will empower you to write those programs with ease. This course is the prerequisites for all other CS courses, but why are you taking it? For me, I was here to learn. Despite the fact that I love programming, Iâ€™m afraid of computer science, especially those abstract algorithms. To prepare for this course, I read Think Java carefully. Mr. Lau suggested to read the first three chapters, I read it entirely. You can download it on your phone, and read it whenever you take your phone out. You donâ€™t need a full time period, except for the exercises at the end of each chapter. You might find yourself unable to complete the exercise questions like me; if you do, just go back and read about that part again. There are no preferred answers to those questions, so any code that generates the same result are correct. But if you ever wonder, mine is on GitHub. Even with a significant amount of knowledge about programming, you can always find something new here, so donâ€™t just assume you are omniscient. Java is advanced but primitive, stern but nonchalant, expressive yet confusing. Learning Java is like learning a foreign language, you have to practice using it. Thus, I strongly recommend starting the labs early. Similar to those exercises included in Think Java, there are no standard ways to implement them. Therefore, explain to your tutor how you choose to complete the task, donâ€™t let them type the code for you. And you never want your friend to show you their program; it will limit your imagination. This course requires you to think logically, trace whatâ€™s going on. It is a frustrating process, but the good news is, you have a lot of resources. You can ask questions in class, take notes on or annotate important concepts for review. Another option is coming to Mr. Lauâ€™s cougar time. Youâ€™ll find a comfortable environment for studying computer science. If you have any questions, you can always ask Mr. Lau or students around you. A lot of â€œgoodâ€ students and center tutors come on daily bases. They will always help you IFF you ask. Or join Oakton Computer Science Club, youâ€™ll find many opportunities to practice what you learned in this course, and meet with some really advanced students. You can be a good student too. Itâ€™s very simple: understand what you are doing. Never use a code snippet until you can write it and its variations out without any assistance. Iâ€™m definitely talking about plagiarism, but thatâ€™s not my focus. I want to emphasis on the importance of solving problems by yourself. If you canâ€™t visualize the process in your head, draw a graph, a table, or a stack to visualize the flow of your program. If your program doesnâ€™t compile, read the error messages. A lot of them doesnâ€™t make any sense to you (and me), but youâ€™ll find the culprit through these traces. If you have a logic error, try break points. They are very easy to learn and convenient to use. Youâ€™ll find them handy. Other than understanding how it works, you need to know why it works. You can achieve this by reading the source code of Java. Written by top developers in the world, Java source code demonstrates the conventions of writing Java code. You can compare your own solutions to theirs, and ask yourself whatâ€™s the difference. With a lot of documentations and comments, you can figure out why they choose to do it that way. Of course Iâ€™m not asking you to read all 2 billion lines of Java code, thatâ€™s neither necessary nor efficient. When Mr. Lau tell you â€œthis is not natural,â€ it is a good place to start. If you have a professional IDE like Eclipse, just ctrl/command click on that method or class; otherwise, find it in the JAVA_HOME directory. A quick note for those â€œgoodâ€ students. You may use â€œadvancedâ€ stuff â€“ such as regular expressions and lambdas â€“ in your lab. Thatâ€™s what people use in real life, but make sure you know how to complete the tasks without those language features, fancy methods, and classes. Remember: ALL are equal before computer science; (to be) || !(to be), that is true. @ApolloZhu 2017/5/24

Justin Li) has the opportunity to participate in this yearâ€™s ACSL All-Star Contest in southern California on May 27. I am very excited for them, and I think this is a very good experience for them to participate the activities outside school and see other students who share the same interest and passion with them from all over the country. My husband will be happy to be the chaperone. I have already purchased the air tickets for the four of them, reserved the hotel rooms, and rented a car last night. I would like to know if there is anything else that needs to be done to participate in this event to represent Oakton High School (like certain forms, school permissions, etc.). Last, I would like to thank you for acting as the groupâ€™s mentor and guiding them for the past two years. I am pretty sure they would not have been able to make it without your help. entry.title: Exam Appendix -- Java Quick Reference
entry.content: Accessible methods from the Java library that may be included on the exam 1234class java.lang.Object { boolean equals(Object other); String toString();} 12345678class java.lang.Integer { Integer(int value); int intValue(); /** Minimum value represented by an `int` or `Integer`. */ static int MIN_VALUE; /** Maximum value represented by an `int` or `Integer`. */ static int MAX_VALUE;} 1234class java.lang.Double { Double(double value); double doubleValue();} 1234567891011class java.lang.String implements java.lang.Comparable<String> { int length(); /** @return the substring beginning at `from` and ending at `to-1`. Note: the substring has length of `to - from`. */ String substring(int from, int to); /** @return `substring(from, length())`. */ String substring(int from); /** @return the index of the first occurrence of `str`; -1 if not found. */ int indexOf(String str); /** @return value < 0 if `this` less than `other`; 0 if equals to `other`; > 0 if greater than `other`. Note: According to ACSII. */ int compareTo(String other);} 1234567class java.lang.Math { static int abs(int x); static double abs(double x); static double pow(double base, double exponent); static double sqrt(double x); static double random();} 123456789101112interface java.util.List<E> { int size(); /** Appends obj to end of list. @return `true` Note: only if operation allowed, such as always true for `ArrayList`. */ boolean add(E obj); /** Inserts `obj` at position `index`, for 0 â‰¤ `index` â‰¤ `size()`. */ void add(int index, E obj) E get(int index); /** Replaces the element at position `index` with `obj`. @return the element formerly at the specified position. */ E set(int index, E obj); /** Removes element from position `index`, moving elements at position `index + 1` and higher to the left by 1 (subtracts 1 from their indices) and adjusts size. @return the element formerly at the specified position. */ E remove(int index);} 1class java.util.ArrayList<E> implements java.util.List<E> { }
